case_vignette: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month! The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes she feels as though she is spinning! Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position! They also sometimes happen when she suddenly turns her head to look at something! She has no nausea! Last month, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously! She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide! Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities! There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead!
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been experiencing several episodes of dizziness over the last month, where it feels like I am spinning. These episodes last for about 30 to 40 seconds and typically happen when I lie down, sit up quickly from a reclining position, or suddenly turn my head.
Do you experience any other symptoms during these episodes like hearing loss, ringing in your ears, or nausea?
No, I do not have any nausea, hearing loss, or ringing in my ears during these episodes.
Have you experienced any recent head injuries or infections involving your ears?
Last month, I had an upper respiratory tract infection, but it resolved on its own.
Do you have any family history of vertigo or inner ear disorders?
I don't have any information about a family history of vertigo or inner ear disorders.
Final Diagnosis: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
